item.title: AARP Answers: Social Security and Coronavirus
item.description:
@ds63646152  SSA requires originals or certified copies from the agency that provided the original. While this article is focused on getting a replacement card, it includes the same list of what is needed:

https://www.aarp.org/retirement/social-security/questions-answers/replacement-ss-card/


Here are a few suggestions to safeguard your information: 

- Get certified copies of your documents from the issue agencies so that you are not sending your original documents. 

- Send the documents by certified mail, insure it, and require a delivery signature so you can confirm receipt by the SSA office.

- Place a fraud alert on your credit with any one of the main bureaus (TransUnion, Experian, Equifax), which would alert you if anyone is trying to open credit in her name. This would be a backstop IF your data were compromised. Another option is to place a credit freeze with each credit agency. 


You could wait for offices to re-open if you still feel uncomfortable with these options. 

-- SOURCE: http://www.aarp.org/retirement/social-security/info-2020/social-security-coronavirus-faq.html
